clinical_study.brief_title: U/S Guided SAB VS U/S Guided SAB With Modified Pectoral Nerve Block in Modified Radical Mastectomy
clinical_study.official_title: U/S Guided SAB VS U/S Guided SAB With Modified Pectoral Nerve Block in Modified Radical Mastectomy,Randomized Double Blinded Comparative Study

brief_summary.textblock: We hypothesize that ultrasound guided serratus anterior plane block Combined With Modified Pectoral Nerve Block is going to be more effective than Ultrasound guided Serratus anterior plane block alone in patients undergoing MRM as modified Pecs block involves the block of medial and lateral pectoral nerves which are spared in case of serratus block alone, resulting in reducing myofascial pain and opioid consumption.

detailed_description.textblock:
Ultrasound guided Serratus anterior plane block was introduced in 2013 for analgesia of breast and lateral thoracic wall surgery. At the axillary fossa, the intercostobrachialis nerve, lateral cutaneous branches of the intercostal nerves (T3-T9), long thoracic nerve, and thoracodorsal nerve are located in a compartment between the serratus anterior and the latissimus dorsi muscles, between the posterior and midaxillary lines at this plane local anesthetic will be injected . Complications of serratus anterior plane block include local anesthetic toxicity and pneumothorax , unfortunately medial and lateral pectoral nerves are preserved which are responsible for the myofacial pain .
The pectoral nerves (Pecs) block types I and II (Modified Pectoral block) , is less invasive technique described by Blanco et al where local anesthetic is deposited into the plane between the pectoralis major muscle(PMm) and the pectoralis minor muscle (Pmm) (Pecs I block)and above the serratus anterior muscle at the third rib (Pecs IIblock).,Blocking intercostobrachial, third to sixth intercostals the long thoracic nerves in addition to medial and lateral pectoral nerves.
Addition of Modified Pecs block to Serratus anterior plane block will enhance the control of pain as it block the medial and lateral pectoral nerves which are responsible for the myofacial pain and which are spared in case of Serratus block alone .

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: To determine the analgesic effect of ultrasound guided Serratus anterior block combined with modified pectoral nerve block compared to ultrasound guided Serratus Anterior block in patients undergoing modified radical mastectomy regarding the following : 1-Post-operative opioid (morphine) consumption in the 1st 24 hours 2- Post-operative Numeric Pain Rating Scale. 3. Effect on hemodynamics: Mean arterial blood pressure and Heart rate. 4. Intraoperative fentanyl consumption. 5. Duration of analgesic effect
study_design_info.masking_description: The patients will be randomly assigned into two equal comparable groups using computer- generated random numbers in opaque closed envelopes, each of which will include 30 patients. Randomization will be done by statistician and each group of the patient will revealed only when the included patient is transferred to preanesthetic room.

primary_outcome.measure: The total amount of morphine consumption in the first 24 hours postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: The total amount of morphine consumption in the first 24 hours postoperatively

secondary_outcome.measure: Total amount of intraoperative fentanyl will be recorded.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative
secondary_outcome.description: Total amount of intraoperative fentanyl will be recorded.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in heart rate and mean arterial blood pressure intraoperatively at 30 minutes interval in comparison to baseline reading.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative
secondary_outcome.description: Change in heart rate and mean arterial blood pressure intraoperatively at 30 minutes interval in comparison to baseline reading.

secondary_outcome.measure: The degree of postoperative sedation according to Ramsay scores
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative .
secondary_outcome.description: postoperative sedation according to Ramsay scores

secondary_outcome.measure: Heart rate, mean arterial blood pressure and VAS (at rest and during movement) at 0, 4, 8, 12, 16, 20 and 24 hours postoperatively.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative
secondary_outcome.description: Change in hemodynamics ((heart rate and mean arterial blood pressure)

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) as side effects of morphine.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative
secondary_outcome.description: Nausea and vomiting Scores using a four-point verbal scale:

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative

secondary_outcome.measure: Complications related to blocks such as local anaesthetic systemic toxicity, pneumothorax and arterial puncture (US check postoperative).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative
secondary_outcome.description: Complications related to blocks such as local anaesthetic systemic toxicity, pneumothorax and arterial puncture

secondary_outcome.measure: Morphine related complications such as respiratory depression, urine retention or pruritis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative
secondary_outcome.description: Morphine related complications such as respiratory depression, urine retention or pruritis

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient satisfaction the patient will be classified in this group to satisfied or not.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through Study Completion over the first 24 hrs postoperative
secondary_outcome.description: Patient satisfaction the patient will be classified in this group to satisfied or not.

clinical_study.condition: U/S Guided SAB VS U/S Guided SAB Combined With Modified Pectoral Nerve Block

arm_group.description: N=3o Patients will receive Ultrasound guided Serratus Anterior Plane Block with injection of 30 ml levobupivacaine 0.25%.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Group 2 ((Serratus Anterior Plane Block SAPB combined with Modified Pectoral Nerve Block)
arm_group.description: N=3o Patients will receive Ultrasound guided Serratus Anterior Plane Block with injection of 20 ml levobupivacaine 0.25%and Modified Pectoral Nerve Block with injection of 10 ml levobupivacaine 0.25%between the two pectoralis muscles, after that, the probe was turned toward the axilla, and as the serratus anterior muscle was recognized above the third and fourth ribs, 10 mL of levobupivacaine 0.25% was injected above this muscle

intervention.description: SAPB Technique; U/S probe will be placed on the patient's midaxillary line in the transverse plane, at the level of the fifth rib, Then, using U/S guidance, A 38-mm 22-gauge regional block needle is advanced in-plane at an angle of approximately 45 degrees towards the fifth rib. After aspiration to avoid IV injection 30ml of levobupivacaine 0.25% is injected anteriorly to the rib and deep to the serratus anterior muscle. SAPB combined with Modified Pectoral Nerve Block : SAPB with injection of 20 ml levobupivacaine 0.25% as discussed before. Modified Pectoral Nerve Block:After identification of the axillary vessels, the U/S probe will turned inferolaterally till the serratus anterior and the two pectoralis muscles are detected in one plane. 10 ml of levobupivacaine 0.25%was injected between the two pectoralis muscles. After that,10 mL of levobupivacaine 0.25%is injected above this muscle.
intervention.arm_group_label: Group 2 ((Serratus Anterior Plane Block SAPB combined with Modified Pectoral Nerve Block)
intervention.other_name: Serratus Anterior Plane Block SAPB combined with Modified Pectoral Nerve Block

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female patients
- Type of surgery; Modified Radical Mastectomy (MRM)
- Physical status ASA I, II, III.
- Age ≥ 18 and ≤ 65 Years.
- Body mass index (BMI): > 20 kg/m2 and < 35 kg/m2.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age <18 years or >65 years
- BMI <20 kg/m2 and >35 kg/m2
- Known sensitivity or contraindication to drug used in the study (local anaesthetics, opioids).
- History of psychological disorders and/or chronic pain.
- Contraindication to regional anaesthesia e.g. local sepsis, pre- existing peripheral neuropathies and coagulopathy.
- Patient refusal.
- Severe respiratory or cardiac disorders.
- Advanced liver or kidney disease.
- Pregnancy.
- Physical status ASA IV and Male patients.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor of Anesthesia &I.C.U and Pain Clinic, Cairo University
